title: Recognizing blends: first experiments with Pybossa
segmentation: Here.

So today we will talk about recognizing blends and this is an Apollos study, which we did to work with the Barbosa crowdsourcing platform and this is joint work of me and Donna Conheim from the Institute for the Dutch language.
Well, very small introduction over Institute or a more expensive set already about this this morning, but we're a scholarly Institute in the first Dutch language an we try.
We do research with Dutch language and we distribute corpora, dictionaries, selectica and grammars.
For the whole Dutch speaking world, so Netherlands Flanders.
Certain Amanda does Caribbean Dutch Caribbean.
Our Institute consists of both linguists.
And people who are more technically skilled like software engineers and system administrators, and this is also important for what we're going to show next.
Current projects the Institute is working on our number of contemporary and historical dictionaries, number of big texts, text files, corpora.
We have a grammar portal.
the Dutch language spelling database terminology lists for certain areas.
We work in the clearing European infrastructure for the Netherlands and Flanders.
There are also a number of new projects at the IIT which are more educationally geared.
Those include bilingual dictionaries.
Those are meant for translators, but it can also be used by language learners for from Dutch to new Greek, Portuguese an Estonian.
Next to that, there's a we are working on a. Corpus of word combinations which can also be used by language learners to learn the specific combinations of verbs and nouns with other words.
In the Dutch language.
And we're working on a corpus of elementary Dutch.
Ann, well, the question this presentation is an we're and part of project is how we can use crowdsourcing in future.
Well to collect information about the Dutch language, but also to improve these.
This language learning resources.
Did general research objective of crowdsourcing is that you?
This will let users off task and it doesn't really matter which user solves the task, but the task has to be solved and also the answer is not always known beforehand.
Well, in a more traditional social linguistics survey, you really care about who the user is who filled in the survey.
Well, what we're going to do is actually a combination of both, so we do crowdsourcing want to solve a specific task, but we also want to know who solved it.
For this, we're going to use the platform by Boussa, which has been introduced at an earlier conference, which can be a suitable platform, and we also look at different alternatives.
I will now describe how we installed Barbosa.
It is possible to use Barbosa.
Host it on an existing platform so you just have to create an account.
But as we already have an arty infrastructure with servers for different corpora and dictionaries, we yeah we have this flexibility and we want to have a more flexible platform for ourselves.
So we decided to install it on own server.
There is a very clear installation guide on the Powerball so website, so it is a doable task, but at the same time it's also.
It's also it has some complexity since Barbosa consists of a number of software packages.
It's not just for both, but it's more packages which have to interact with each other.
So this makes the installation tasks task a bit more complex, but we create the script so it's also reproducible so we can do it again for if we want to create a new server.
So I would say that the take home message is that it is.
If you want to work with Barbosa, it is possible to do it on a hosted platform and you can also do it yourself, but if you have a good party infrastructure.
Well, the part of project we did with Barbosa.
There was a project with blends and blends are compounds of two words were parts of the words have been blended.
And compound word has a new meaning which is related to the words it consists of.
So examples both in Dutch and English are glamping which consists of glamour and camping.
An well this is very unknown one, but map amillennial and Yup.

Blends are related to two projects.
We have the IT they are part of the General Dutch Dictionary.
The A&W.
And so they are in that in the dictionary, together with a lot of other words.
And there is an upcoming neologisms portal which will contain the same Neola gism, so, but also other neologisms which are not in a dictionary but which.
Which are, for example, which are more scarcely used or which are more recent and have not yet been rooted in the language.
Then we put him in a new Legion portal, and a more rooted new legitimes we put them in the in the General Dictionary.

We have a workflow other institutes to extract these new legitimes we get data from newspapers and websites and we automatically process the man look at which words are new and unknown and we put them aside and then a linguist electrical lexicographer selection eulogy Sims and then were according to what type of neurologist in this puts the new word in the portal or in the dictionary.
So we have this data we we use it for our task.
So the crowds principle we want the crowd, which is as diverse as possible to really get a good picture of what all people in the Dutch language area think of blends and how they perceive them.
But to keep it easy for this pilot we advertised in our newsletter.
So a lot of language ambitious, they reacted to this and we we took it to our we were present at the Congress of an International Society for Dutch Linguistics and we.
Presented there at our stand there.
So we'll get.
Maybe we have people who know already a bit more about language, but we got quite good.
Quite a large amount of people who filled in the questionnaire, which with not too much hassle actually.
The task we presented two tasks.
The 1st first task was blunt recognition.
So given a citation from the dictionary with the Blanton, it's two people recognize the plant and even do they recognize other words as blends maybe.
And the second task is blend analysis.
So given for example word glamping, can you analyze it that it consists of glamour and camping?
And to make it not too long, we did for each job we presented 10 tasks.

Well, now a bit more technical part about how bossa works, so impulsa it's possible to really design your own task and you get a lot of freedom, and that is a benefit and what may be also be downside to depending on what you want, but you really you get the possibility to design the task from the ground up.
So how do task will look within within input books and the buttons and the descriptions?
You can really customize everything using HTML and JavaScript.
That works quite well, quite convenient in our case, but it can also be inconvenient if you don't have knowledge of those programming language, for example.
And everything else is handled by Barbosa, so loading task, saving task, the account management, everything is done by Barbosa.

We designed this.
We first ask people for user details, since as already mentioned, we have a combined task and well, not just pure crowdsourcing, but we also want to know some details of our users.
So we ask for their age, gender and location if they want to give it.
They do not have to give it so that looks like this is the first thing they see.
And then they get.

They get a bland, for example adware and they have to say of which 2 words it consists.
And the second task look like this so you get a citation and you have to say which blends are in this citation.
And then you get 10 of those tasks.

We see more female than male and question people who do not want to refill their gender.
For the location also a lot of people who do not want to reveal their location and also a lot of big cities in the Netherlands and Belgium.
Not very surprising, I would say.
